issues.description: The template code uses a non-standard getter name retrieveQuantity() for StockIngredient, while other template files (Stock, Main) and the problem statement expect a conventional getter getQuantity(). This creates a structural mismatch: Stock.add() and Stock.take() call getQuantity(), and Main (commented tests) also calls getQuantity(), but StockIngredient in the template only defines retrieveQuantity(), causing compilation errors and contradicting the problem instruction to “add getters for all the private fields.” The solution repository uses getQuantity(), which confirms the intended API.
issues.suggested_fix: Provide a conventional getter getQuantity() in StockIngredient (returning the current quantity). Either rename retrieveQuantity() to getQuantity(), or add a new getQuantity() that delegates to the existing method. This aligns the template with the problem statement (which asks for getters) and with other template files (Stock, Main) and the solution.

issues.description: The template's StockIngredient class exposes the quantity via a method named retrieveQuantity(), while other code (the Stock class in the template and the reference solution) expects a standard getter named getQuantity(). The problem statement also asks students to "add getters for all the private fields", which implies conventional getter names. This naming mismatch forces students to either rename/add methods to satisfy other classes or to change calls in multiple places, creating unnecessary confusion and likely compile errors.
issues.suggested_fix: Rename the template method retrieveQuantity() to getQuantity() (or add a getQuantity() wrapper that delegates to retrieveQuantity()) so the getter follows standard naming and aligns with calls in Stock and the solution. This preserves the problem instruction to add getters while removing the cross-artifact naming mismatch.
